posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
When the choice of which metamagic feat(s) would put that finishing touch on that build that is starving for help, it's decision time.

Here are the available metamagic versions for each spell of the casting classes... Bard, Cleric, Druid, Paladin, Ranger, Sorcerer & Wizard... in table form. Some may surprise you or leave you scratching your head. In any case, the facts don't lie and are presented here for your perusal.

Note: These are all the vanilla, default settings so check with your favorite server admin or SP module readme to discover whether they have been customized in some way. To determine which slots are needed to cast the metamagic version, just add the number in parenthesis of the column headings to the Spell Level of each "X".

If you notice any inconsistencies with in-game performance (other than due to custom override or hak, that is), please PM me. Also, if you have Excel loaded on your machine and would like the handy, dandy, filterable, sortable spreadsheet (approx 250 Kb), email your request to me at hipmaestro@yahoo.com and I will be happy to forward a copy.

Comment about Auto Metamagic Feats
For paladin and ranger, Quicken Spell is unavailable even though both those classes appear to meet the prerequisite "Cast 4th-level spells". However, if they are multiclassed with a class that can take Quicken Spell and then further qualify for Automatic Quicken Spell I & II, all paladin or ranger spells can be cast in quickened mode.

TABLES
Bard Metamagic
Cleric Metamagic
Druid Metamagic
Paladin Metamagic
Ranger Metamagic
Sorcerer & Wizard Metamagic

Edit (06/25/2014):  Deleted all tables since the new forumer format has not translated BB code properly making all the tables I posted unreadable.   Attempting to reinsert newly-formatted tables in a single post apparently overloads the allowed buffer size for the editor, so each table has been added as a separate post within this topic.  As an alternative, you may prefer to use the metamagic table(s) contained in the NWN Wiki.

Edit (06/28/2014): Bard, Cleric, Druid Metamagic tables have been added and linked.

Edit (06/29/2104): Paladin, Ranger, Sorcerer/Wizard Metamagic tables have been added and linked.

Edit (02.22.2022 by Mick dagger): Added headings to the different tables and cleared some formatting bugs

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
Hip,

Thanks for that. I'm gonna have to take a closer look at those and compare to the wiki. At first glance I saw a couple that look like they should be able to be empowered, but the chart says no.


And I just went and checked one because the curiosity was killing me.

Cure Moderate Wounds for a paladin. My brain was screaming, "Why can't he empower that... thats BS!!!"

hehe.. turns out its cause pally only has 4 levels of spells, and cure moderate empowered would require a level 5 slot. Now I have seen a few worlds where the builder accidentally put bonus spell slots on a pally item for lvl 5. Wonder if that would allow the empowered cure moderate, or for a stilled lvl 4 spell.


Conlaoch

posts.author: HipMaestro
posts.content:
Well, this list was a result of a request of a few of the members of our local LAN group who get annoyed when they take one of the metamagic feats only to find out certain spells can't be slotted like they anticipated. There aren't all that many, but enough exceptions to leave some of us wondering why BioWare parsed it the way they did. Like Lesser Dispel. Why the heck can't it be quickened while Dispel Magic can? There are a few other examples.

The columns themselves are simply a conversion of Bioware's mystical hex sum in the 2da that determines which metamagic applies to which spell. So if test data varies, it means I had a temporary loss of reflexes juggling cells, which is certainly a possibility.

So my guess to your hypothetical "What if..." would be "Yes" in both cases, in effect a spell casted like a druid.

How it is implemented, though, may determine the true scope because it must appear in the spell book to select the metamagic version. Adding custom slots would imply they (the custom designers) had a spell (or spells) in mind to be selected, perhaps some that would not normally be considered a pally spell, similar to a cleric domain. Best to check with the admin to understand the consequences of adding that sort of item property within their PW.

Now here's a question I would love to include in this thread if anyone has tested it or has empirical knowledge of the dynamic:

Are all/any of the feat-granted spells (like assassin's Darkness) affected by the Auto Metamagic feats? (I'm including all the shifter casting shapes in that question as well.)

posts.author: conlaoch
posts.content:
HipMaestro wrote:
Are all/any of the feat-granted spells (like assassin's Darkness) affected by the Auto Metamagic feats? (I'm including all the shifter casting shapes in that question as well.)
Well, I know some of them can't be scribed. I've had wizard/Assassins and their Ghostly Visage, darkness, and Invisibility can't be put onto a scroll.


Conlaoch

posts.author: hunearo
posts.content:
conlaoch wrote:
Hip,

Thanks for that. I'm gonna have to take a closer look at those and compare to the wiki. At first glance I saw a couple that look like they should be able to be empowered, but the chart says no.


And I just went and checked one because the curiosity was killing me.

Cure Moderate Wounds for a paladin. My brain was screaming, "Why can't he empower that... thats BS!!!"

hehe.. turns out its cause pally only has 4 levels of spells, and cure moderate empowered would require a level 5 slot. Now I have seen a few worlds where the builder accidentally put bonus spell slots on a pally item for lvl 5. Wonder if that would allow the empowered cure moderate, or for a stilled lvl 4 spell.


Conlaoch
"Every spell-casting class technically has spell slots for levels 0 through 9, even though the quasi-casters (bards, paladins, and rangers) are never given the upper level spell slots on the basis of class level. Those higher slots can be awarded by an item though, which could allow metamagic to be applied to the quasi-casters' highest level spells. This may require those spells to be flagged as usable with metamagic and (if the metamagic is to have effect) possibly to have metamagic support added to their scripts." Wikia

It sounds to me that with the right items at hand your pally could empower that cure spell. However I don't know if it would worth to mark these spells in the tables, AFAIK there aren't any standard bioware items like this.

posts.author: HipRedux
posts.content:
hunearo wrote:
"Every spell-casting class technically has spell slots for levels 0 through 9, even though the quasi-casters (bards, paladins, and rangers) are never given the upper level spell slots on the basis of class level. Those higher slots can be awarded by an item though, which could allow metamagic to be applied to the quasi-casters' highest level spells. This may require those spells to be flagged as usable with metamagic and (if the metamagic is to have effect) possibly to have metamagic support added to their scripts." Wikia

It sounds to me that with the right items at hand your pally could empower that cure spell. However I don't know if it would worth to mark these spells in the tables, AFAIK there aren't any standard bioware items like this.
Just like on the NWNwiki, the ECB Guild's factoids and guides refer to vanilla v3.0 (or NWN's version of it anyway).   One could easily add class-specific slots up to level 9 to an item to vastly extend the vanilla class's spellcasting abilities for all the metamagic feats, and not just for pally, but any class that has a max spell level lower than 9.  Within a custom environment (mostly likely a high-magic one) that adds these sorts of properties, a modified table may be of some use.  For vanilla NWN?  None.
